name: NPR
text: Most of the U.S. will "fall back" during Sunday's wee hours. Many sleep researchers say daylight saving time does more harm than good. https://t.co/aEb0lTeIJV

name: NPR
text:
Police reform measures are on the Nov. 3 ballot in several cities and states. From establishing civilian oversight to shifting money toward social services, here's a look at what changes are being sought:
 https://t.co/eJOdC2Nqz6

name: NPR
text: For Democrats, flipping just a few seats could mean taking majority control of a chamber in several state legislatures. Here are the races to watch. https://t.co/K9z6jWm1PD

name: NPR
text:
Our correspondent @AubreyNPR evaluates Joe Biden's proposed plan to tackle the coronavirus.

name: NPR
text:
If you've been on edge about the election, your kids have noticed. Because they're naturally self-centered, they'll assume your stress is about them.

Here's @NPRLifeKit's primer on how to talk with them about it: https://t.co/sXHrx2GPVt

name: NPR
text: England will enter a second coronavirus lockdown beginning on Thursday that is scheduled to run until early December, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said. https://t.co/3YeIO3Imrq

name: NPR
text:
Two days after George Floyd was killed, Anthony McGill used his clarinet to offer a musical response to systemic racism and violence.

Hear him speak about the intersection of artistry and activism — and the surprising paths we sometimes take to get there:
https://t.co/4082GcK6lz

name: NPR
text:
Mike Murphy consults for the group Republican Voters Against Trump, so @waitwait invited him to play a game called "Consulting, meet insulting" — three questions about insults through the ages.
 https://t.co/8EuH1iIPko
